channel.title: Microsoft Server Software
channel.description:
I'm just curious about whether there'd be interest in using the Microsoft stack (Windows Server 2012, SQL Server 2012, .NET) if a C# server existed. The main concern that comes to my mind is the licencing.
Discuss.

item.title: Microsoft Server Software
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

There’s the express edition, but it has a 1GB limit on RAM usage. In short, it would have very inadequate caching capabilities and probably wouldn’t be appropriate in production.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft Server Software
item.dc:creator: @zerratar zerratar
item.description:
@zerratar wrote:

eFox:

I don’t understand why it isn’t relevant, why go to the effort of changing to MS if what is currently used isn’t a weak link?

In that case then its mostly by preferences, if a developer enjoys .net more than java for instance.
but this isn’t about how well a server is coded nor managed. It is just a discussion, if we had a server developed in .net, and you were deciding to use it. Would you think its worth it by using a windows server 2012.

Therefor I didn’t see how asking about why rsc private servers isn’t holding up was relevant to this topic.

I did not mean to offend you, I’m sorry if I did.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft Server Software
item.dc:creator: @zerratar zerratar
item.description:
@zerratar wrote:

eFox:

Why do RSC servers fail? Will this help at all with that problem?

That has nothing to do with this discussion.

The reason for “all” private RSC servers dies is because not many of the developers earn any money on it, there’s just no dedication to it in the end.

Anyway back to the discussion.
I would probably not use a dedicated windows server 2012 due to the high costs. Altough that also depends on if there is any revenue hosting the server, otherwise its not just worth it.
In my case I would probably host it myself. I have a few servers running at home already. But for those who doesn’t, should (if hosting anything using a dedicated windows server) check earlier versions as alternatives. And keep in mind… Don’t use Hyper-V if you’re simply hosting a game server where you only got tops 100 users at the time. They cost an arm and a leg. (hope that was valid for this discussion)

On another thought, hosting on a virtual machine; running windows server 2012 should not be overwhelming expensive.

Note: ordinary dedicated with windows server 2012 + SQL Server 2012 can vary between 150$ and 500$.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft Server Software
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

VC++ 2012 supports C++11 concurrency. And in terms of overall C++11 support new compiler updates are supposed to come in 1-2 months.

As far as I know MinGW doesn’t support threading yet. And then there’s TDM-GCC. These GCC ports for Windows create a lot of confusion.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft Server Software
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

C++ doesn’t have the same concurrency memory model that C# and Java have. Well, C++11 specification covers concurrency but I’m not sure what the implementation progress is like.

Read full topic
